Kendall |birth_name = Donald Mcintosh Kendall |birth_date = {{Birth date and age|1921|3|16}} |birth_place = [[Sequim, Washington]], U.S. |death_date = |death_place = |occupation = Businessman, political adviser}} '''Donald Mcintosh Kendall''' (born March 16, 1921) is a former businessman, political adviser. He is a former CEO of [[Pepsi Cola]] (which merged with [[Herman Lay]]'s [[Frito-Lay|Frito Lay, Inc.]] to become [[Pepsi|PepsiCo]] in 1965) and served as [[CEO]] of PepsiCo from 1971 to 1986. ==Biography== ===Early life=== He was born in [[Clallam County, Washington]], where his family owned a dairy farm, in 1921. ===Pepsi Cola, Inc.=== He joined Pepsi Cola Company as a sales representative and rose through the sales ranks becoming a marketing vice president in 1956. He headed up Pepsi's international operation in 1957 and became president in 1963. In 1963, he made the decision to change the name of Pepsi's diet soda from [[Patio Diet Cola]] to [[Diet Pepsi]]. In the early years of diet soft drinks, Pepsi became the first major soda manufacturer to give its diet product the same name as its flagship product. {{Citation needed|date=June 2013}} In 1970, he requested and participated in a high level meeting of Chilean businessman and publisher [[Edwards family|Augustin Edwards Eastman]] with high Nixon administration officials, after which President Nixon met with then-National Security Adviser [[Henry Kissinger]] and CIA Director [[Richard Helms]] and, in the words of a 1976 ''New York Times'' article, said "that Chile was to be saved from [[Salvador Allende|Allende]] and he didn't care much how."<ref>Russ Baker, ''Family of Secrets'' (Bloomsbury Press, 2009), p. 187.</ref> According to ''The Guardian'' (UK), "...the October 1970 plot against Chile's President-elect Salvador Allende ... was the direct result of a plea for action a month earlier by Donald Kendall, chairman of PepsiCo, in two telephone calls to the company's former lawyer, President Richard Nixon. Kendall arranged for the owner of the company's Chilean bottling operation to meet National Security Adviser Henry Kissinger on September 15. Hours later, Nixon called in his CIA chief, Richard Helms, and, according to Helms's handwritten notes, ordered the CIA to prevent Allende's inauguration."<ref name=Palast>{{cite news|last=Palast|first=Gregory|title=A Marxist threat to cola sales? Pepsi demands a US coup. Goodbye Allende. Hello Pinochet|url=http://www.guardian.co.uk/Columnists/Column/0,,305870,00.html|accessdate=January 5, 2013|newspaper=The Guardian|date=November 8, 1998}}</ref> He had a stormy professional relationship with actress [[Joan Crawford]], who referred to Kendall as "Fang" until her death in 1977. Crawford gained a seat on the board of directors of Pepsi Cola Company after the death of her husband Alfred Steele. She was active in promoting Pepsi-Cola, traveling both nationally and internationally for events such as plant openings and new product promotions. In 1973, when Crawford officially turned 65 (she was actually two or three years older), she was forcibly retired from her position on the company's Board of Directors. {{Citation needed|date=June 2013}} Kendall was well acquainted with [[Richard Nixon]] and was photographed with Nixon as Vice President, and with [[Nikita Khrushchev]] during Nixon's [[Moscow]] trip known for the [[Kitchen Debate]]. During the Nixon administration [[Pepsi Cola]] was always a prominent beverage at White House functions. A conversation between Kendall and Nixon in the oval office appears in the second volume of the Watergate tapes. Kendall is heard offering advice to Nixon on how to handle his difficult situation. He later told an interviewer that he was "disappointed" at the way Nixon handled Watergate. "How could you help but be?"<ref>Arthur M. Louis, ''The Tycoons'' (Simon & Schuster, 1981), p. 92.</ref> Kendall brought Pepsi to Russia and was awarded the Order of Friendship by [[Vladimir Putin]], President of [[Russia]], in 2004. He oversaw the creation of the [[Donald M. Kendall Sculpture Gardens]], a [[sculpture park]] that includes gardens, trails and parks a collection of art, primarily 20th century sculpture including works by Rodin, Wynn and Calder, at PepsiCo's corporate headquarters in [[Purchase, New York]]. {{Citation needed|date=June 2013}} ==References== {{reflist|2}} ==External links== * [http://www.beverageforum.com/bevforumbios2004.htm Biographical sketch of Kendall] {{Persondata <!-- Metadata: see [[Wikipedia:Persondata]]. --> | NAME = Kendall,Donald M | ALTERNATIVE NAMES = | SHORT DESCRIPTION = | DATE OF BIRTH = March 16, 1921 | PLACE OF BIRTH = [[Sequim, Washington]], U.S. | DATE OF DEATH = | PLACE OF DEATH = }} {{DEFAULTSORT:Kendall, Donald M}} [[Category:PepsiCo people]] [[Category:1921 births]] [[Category:People from Sequim, Washington|Kendall, Donald M.]] [[Category:Living people]]
